job_title: Practice Coordinator in Browns Mills, NJ
pros: None.. well no some staff is nice there, otherwise nothing
cons: I was hired there to reopen the endocrinology departments which I did and I did well they hired me that was the last time I saw a ministration for a year I had no computer no training on their EMR system no paperwork nothing not even a blood pressure cuff or gloves to start my office I had nothing I created that office from scratch. I was told I would be managing and growing on top of the endocrinology departments after a year I realized that was all lies it was still only me and the physician that worked there after a year though we had full schedules of patience a wait list 6 months long to get in to see us we still did not have any help I was janitor to manager with only a doctor and thousands of patients. Did my patients have the best care yes they did was I on top of all their prior authorizations or the paperwork or their appointments all the reminders all their medications all their education or their trainings yes I was. Did Deborah at all in the administration care no they did not they don't care about the patients and they sure as hell don't give a crap about their staff. they just pile on more and more and more and more and more and more and more and more and more and more and more and more work while they sit behind a desk clueless and don't help at all. Finally after a year they hired a third administration person just to drive around and gaslight people smile in their face and gaslight them literally did nothing you paid a person to drive around and do nothing instead of hiring people to actually help your staff. After 2 years I was so worn down and my father passed away do you want to know what administration the only people above me my bosses said to me when will you be back to work not sorry about your loss not anything when will you be back to work cuz it can't run without me there's no other staff there's no coverage I can't get sick I can't do anything. Then have the audacity to save even more money and get more bonuses for the administration that does absolutely nothing but sit behind a desk and make bad decisions on how to make more money in their pocket but not how to help staff not how to help patients nothing like that they going to get the cheapest EMR so it's 20 times more paperwork for their staff even more horrible communication between patients they destroyed it and all they did was sit behind their desk and when people said well we're going to need this before it happens this is going to happen before it happens they did nothing they did absolutely nothing and just waited for their staff to cover their butt the day it happens.. and when staff is done and looks at him and says you made these stupid mistakes get off your butt and do it yourself they don't appreciate it so much.. all this for minimum wage the lowest pay you'll get in any area of New Jersey you can go and be a janitor at Wawa and make more money than a manager at the Deborah and if you're a nurse you will be making the lowest pay around good luck.. oh wait there's more if you're looking for insurance this is not the place I broke my tibia and went into financial ruin because of the insurance so now there's really not one perk to this place unless you want to be overworked underpaid underappreciated oh wait your Christmas bonus was a $5 wawa card yay.. don't worry administration got big bonuses...

job_title: SICU RN in Browns Mills, NJ
pros: Family environment, The CEO and CNO round on units and know your name. Physicians are top notch and respect their nurses-treat them like friends/family.
cons:
Pay doesn't seem fair for the acuity of patients we receive. Fresh out of the OR after heart, lung or vascular surgery, incredibly unstable with IABP, Impella, Ecmo, LVADS, CRRT with ~10-15 titratable gtts including pressors, paralytics, sedatives, pain meds, inotropes. etc. with 1:1, 1:2, or 1:3 patients ratio. 

ICU nurses float to ANY unit in the hospital including Triage/ER and medsurg with a full load of patients when the unit has call outs or is understaffed with no financial compensation- no float pay

job_title: Registered Nurse in Browns Mills, NJ
pros: It's such a small hospital, that the staff is very much like family. Everyone is very approachable and nice. You will learn a lot about cardiac medicine. It's one of the 3 hospitals in the country where patients don't pay for their care.
cons: Staffing can be a nightmare. The hospital is small, and because of that, resources are not abundant. There is no float pool for nursing staff, and they just pull you anywhere they need you, a lot of times leaving ICU staff short as a result.

review_title: DEBORAH still has it's priorities right - Top Quality Care first and foremost!
job_title: Registered Nurse in Browns Mills, NJ
pros:
DEBORAH is a hospital that "gets it".  The quality of patient care and satisfaction of the patient and their families are still the top priority.  All outside rating firms rank DEBORAH at or among the top in the country for cardiac, pulmonary and vascular care.  In spite of the financial difficulties associated with hospitals in New Jersey, DEBORAH hasn't wavered on this.
The Mission of DEBORAH is also very unique, and gives us all a very positive feeling that what we do really matters!
Working at DEBORAH is great.  There's very much a feeling of "family".  Even when difficult decisions need to be made, the Administration really seems to care about staff, and works to do what they have to do in a way that is most fair to staff.  We all help each other out, and take pride in doing a great job.  I would highly recommend DEBORAH as a place to work.
cons: It's unique Mission makes the financial challenges difficult to deal with.  We have had some cut-backs, but they were done in a fair and humane way.  Staffing is still much better than most hospitals I've worked at.

review_title: Good place to start your career but not to stay for the long term.
job_title: Sterile Processing Technician in Browns Mills, NJ
pros: A lot of good people work here. You have your individuals in every organization but overall people are friendly. There isn't a union but you have to really, really, mess up bad in order to get fired. Tuition assistance is provided and they pay it directly to you before your classes begin...much better than a reimbursement. Just maintain a 'C' average or higher or else you'll have to repay the tuition. (you can pay back little by little each check though) Benefits used to be VERY good from free and low cost health coverage, free lunch, and many others that made up for the low pay. Every hospital/organization has cut back on benefits but Deborah hasn't caught up with them on pay. This is on almost all levels/positions. It's great to come and get great experience and work with great people but if you're looking to for more pay and or/advancement this is not the place to stay.
cons: Low pay. If you live nearby it may not be too bad as the higher paying jobs are further away but all in all the pay is still low.

review_title: One of the best places I've ever worked.
job_title: Patient Dispatcher in Browns Mills, NJ
pros: Deborah offers great perks.  Time off earned is fantastic.  It's also a non profit organization which I was very proud to work at.  Most everyone there works as a team and very loving and caring co-workers.   Many people are not aware that Deborah would never send anyone a bill.  Not even if you didn't have a dime to pay for your care.  Deborah has a wonderful volunteer staff as well.
cons: I hurt my shoulder and was out of work for over 6 months due to recovery and I lost my job.  It's unfortunate they couldn't work with me a bit better to help me get back into work there.  I have many talents and 5 star reviews for the 11 years I worked there.  I still love Deborah and what they do for people.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Pemberton, NJ
pros: A true non-profit hospital...never once since 1922 has a patient been balance-billed or asked for a co-payment or deductible.  Friendly and family-like atmosphere and co-workers.  Decent benefits.  Above excellent nurses, physicians, clinicians...most everyone from Housekeeping through non-clinical staff!
cons: Pay scale vs. workload could be much better!  Especially for non-clinical staff.  Some (not all) Executive-level staff could take a better interest in their employees.  Time-frame from when a patient calls and leaves a message to receiving a return call could be better...however, staffing is well below what's needed!

review_title: May want to wait for conditions to improve before applying here.  Hopefully the upswing will be soon.
job_title: Nursing Assistant in Browns Mills, NJ
pros: The hospital is known as a charitable hospital, never billing patients and operating off donations and what insurance pays only. It is a small enough facility that you can feel as though you are really able to attend to your patients' needs.  The majority of the staff is truly dedicated to their work and their patients, and much of the staff exhibit strong loyalty and have been employed by Deborah for decades.  Tuition assistance and repayment are available for related fields of study, and educational advancement is encouraged. Though termination of employment "for any reason" is a reserved right by the organization, arbitrary firings do not occur.  Scheduling is typically flexible for shiftworkers. 32 hours per week is considered full time and eligible for benefits.  The benefits package is very good. A new wing of single patient rooms is under construction.
cons: Senior leadership is poor, and apparent recent mismanagement of funds is causing massive layoffs.  Wages are low in comparison to surrounding hospitals, raises are capped at a mere 30 cents per year possible - and rarely is the entire 30 cent raise awarded.  This year there were no raises whatsoever.  There are fears that Deborah is a "sinking ship". Billboards, other advertising, and various strategies to enhance patient census are being employed, however, and there is hope for a recovery.  Many NJ hospitals are facing money issues at this time, however, due to recent funding cuts by state government.  We're all facing recession, the question is who will last - hopefully DHLC will.

review_title: Great job at a great organization
job_title: Lead Service Attendant in Browns Mills, NJ
pros: Non profit organization, great employees, like a big family, great pay. Employee perks such as dinners and lunches. Parties, and great recognition for job done and achievements. Tenure gains even better perks. A great place to work over-all. They never charge a patient, only their insurance, and if they have no insurance, it's all free for them.
cons: None really, other than the occasional pay raise freeze due to it being a non profit organization and relying on contributions, donations and payments from insurance providers.
